abstract: Texas Forensic Science Commission is working to develop guidelines on admissibility of bite-mark comparisons in court; inquiry follows cases like that of Steven Mark Chaney, who was freed following 28 years in prison after expert testimony on bite-marks was called into question; issue reflects broader crisis in forensic science as several of its methods come under scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: A report expected next year would be the first formal finding by a state or federal agency on the validity of bite-mark evidence in murder, rape and child abuse cases.

headline.main: Lives in Balance, Texas Leads Scrutiny of Bite-Mark Forensics
headline.print_headline: Lives in Balance, Texas Leads Scrutiny of Bite-Mark Forensics

snippet: A report expected next year would be the first formal finding by a state or federal agency on the validity of bite-mark evidence in murder, rape and child abuse cases.
